metadata.case_name: Former Governor-General of India v. Corporation of Madras & State of Madras

facts.text: Appellant held office as the last Governor-General of India and is entitled to a pension of Rs. 15,000/- per annum under s. 3 of Central Act XXX of 1951, drawing this sum while residing in the city of Madras.

Corporation of Madras (first respondent) demanded profession tax from appellant under s. 111(1)(b) of the City Municipal Act, 1919 for the year 1958-1959 on the ground of appellant's residence within the city and drawing pension.
Appellant communicated to Corporation that demand was illegal as pensioner does not fall under profession, trade, calling or employment.
Corporation insisted on compliance, claiming persons in receipt of pensions liable under express terms of the Act.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Madras High Court seeking writ of prohibition against Corporation, impleading State of Madras, challenging constitutional validity of the levy.
Madras High Court dismissed writ petition by judgment dated May 1, 1961.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c), leading to this appeal.
Madras City Municipal Act IV of 1919 enacted, s.111(1) imposed profession tax, Explanation 2 deemed pensioners as holding appointment.
Madras City Municipal Amendment Act X of 1936 substituted s.111(1), deleted Explanation 2, added s.111(1)(b) for pensioners residing 60 days, required Council resolution under new s.98-A.

Schedule IV in 1919 Act divided persons into classes based on monthly salary/income, sub-classes for appointments and professions etc.; post-1936, argued inapplicable to pensioners without Explanation 2.
Corporation passed resolution on March 31, 1937 under s.98-A to levy profession tax from April 1, 1937 at specified rates.
Schedule IV amended in 1942 by notification under s.347(3), dividing classes on half-yearly income basis, effective April 1, 1942.
Constitution commenced January 26, 1950; GOI Act 1935 Part III commenced April 1, 1937.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Corporation of Madras is entitled to levy profession tax on pensioners in respect of pensions received by them under s.111(1)(b) of the City Municipal Act, 1919.
Whether the tax was lawfully levied prior to commencement of Part III of GOI Act 1935 (April 1, 1937) so as to be saved by s.143(2) thereof, and prior to Constitution so as to be saved by Art.277.
Effect of 1936 Amendment deleting Explanation 2 to s.111 and requiring Council resolution, creating gap in levy from April 1936 to April 1937.
Whether lacuna in Schedule IV rules (unamended till 1942) made levy unlawful from 1937-1942.
Whether rate increases post-1937 made it a new tax not saved.
Whether 1936 Act valid under Devolution Rules/GOI Act 1919.

petitioner_arguments.text: Amending Act X of 1936 invalid as contravening Devolution Rules under GOI Act 1919, as tax on income outside local competence.

Even if 1936 Act valid, tax under s.111(1)(b) is new tax levied first by resolution from April 1, 1937, not existing prior to Part III GOI Act 1935, not saved by s.143(2); statutory charge ceased April 1936.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.143(2) GOI Act 1935; s.111 Madras Act 1919

petitioner_arguments.text: Between April 1, 1937 and April 1, 1942, tax not lawfully levied due to lacuna in Schedule IV rules inapplicable to pensioners post-deletion of Explanation 2.
Rate increases from 1937 (1950,1958,1961) make it new tax, not continuable under s.143(2) or Art.277.
Tax on pension is tax on income (Entry 82 Union List), not on profession etc. (Entry 60 State List).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Schedule VII Constitution; Entry 60 State List

respondent_arguments.text: Tax lawfully levied prior to Constitution and saved by Art.277 as being levied before Jan 26, 1950.
Saved by s.143(2) GOI Act 1935 as lawfully levied prior to Part III (April 1, 1937), via Indo-Burma Order extending reference date.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.143(2) GOI Act 1935; Indo-Burma Transitory Provisions Order 1937 para 3

respondent_arguments.text: 1936 Act continued as existing law under s.292 GOI Act 1935 / Art.372 Constitution.
Pension tax is tax on employment as consideration for past services.
Schedule IV rules continued applicable via s.18 Madras General Clauses Act.

court_reasoning.text: First point on 1936 Act validity under Devolution Rules not decided fully as other points suffice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Infraction validated by ss.80A(3),84(2) GOI Act 1919 prima facie.

court_reasoning.text: 1936 Amendment lifted statutory charge on pensions (April 1936), required Council resolution; new charge from April 1, 1937 via resolution - not 'being lawfully levied' prior to Part III GOI Act 1935.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power to levy != tax being levied; new levy with residence condition and rate change.

court_reasoning.text: Schedule IV unamended till 1942 inapplicable to pensioners post-deletion of Explanation 2; no lawful levy 1937-1942.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules framed for original s.111 with fiction; defect not remedied by General Clauses Act.

court_reasoning.text: Not necessary to decide rate increases effect as base levy invalid.
s.292/Art.372 general, subject to specific s.143(2)/Art.277 for taxes.
s.142A/Entry 46 amended only deems profession tax not income tax if it is on profession etc.; here not on profession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax on pension receipt is income tax.

holdings.text: Corporation not entitled to levy profession tax on pensioners; levy invalid, not saved by s.143(2) GOI Act 1935 or Art.277 Constitution.
1936 Amendment created new levy from 1937, not pre-existing.
Tax on pension is tax on income, outside State power under Entry 60.

precedents_cited.case_name: Town Municipal Committee, Amravati v. Ram Chandra Vasudeo Chimote
precedents_cited.relevance: Power to levy != tax being levied for s.143(2) saving.

precedents_cited.case_name: South India Corporation (P) Ltd. v. Secretary, Board of Revenue, Trivandrum
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.372 subject to Art.277; special provision for taxes prevails.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction, writ, saving of pre-Constitution taxes, legislative powers.

statutes_cited.name: Madras City Municipal Act, 1919
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposed profession tax on pensioners; amendments altered charge.

statutes_cited.name: Madras City Municipal Amendment Act, 1936 (Act X of 1936)
statutes_cited.relevance: Deleted Explanation 2, required resolution for levy.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Saving of pre-existing taxes; legislative competence.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Continuation of rules; rejected by court.

outcome.summary: Appeal succeeds; appellant entitled to writ of prohibition against Corporation of Madras from enforcing profession tax demand on pension; High Court judgment set aside as tax levy invalid.

key_quotes.text: "The mere existence of a power to bring a tax into operation, cannot... be equated with a tax which was being lawfully levied before Part III of the Government of India Act, 1935."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A person in receipt of a pension paid from any source shall be deemed to be a person holding an appointment within the meaning of this section."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explanation 2 to original s.111(1), deleted in 1936.

key_quotes.text: "Taxes on profession, trades, callings and employments."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Entry 60 State List; pension not covered.
